millsfield:images_texts:
Franchise May Be Delayed
Senator Quirino told H. M. Mixby
this morning the franchise
his firm seeks may be delayed. In the photo are shown Attorney
James Ross, Jr., Bixby, Quirino, and Attorney Trias.
BIXBY, QUIRINO
DISCUSS PLAN
Airways Franchise May Suffer
Delay Due To Change Of
Aerial Policy
Due to an impending change of
government policy on the granting
of
air franchises,
no
assurance
can be given that the 25-year fran-
chise requested by the Pan-Amer-
ican Airways to operate a Hong-
kong-Manila.
route
can be
granted immediately, H. M. Bix-
by, vice president of the Pan Am-
erican airways, was informed this
morning by Senator Elpidio Quiri-
no, floor leader of the senate.
(Continued on page 15)

BIXBY AND QUIRINO
DISCUSS FRANCHISE
(Continued from page 1)
Mr. Bixby, who arrived in Ma-
nila yesterday
from Shanghai to
urge approval of the franchise bill,
callled upon Senator Quirino ac-
companied by
Attorneys
James
Ross, Jr., and Trias of the law
firm of Ross, Lawrence and Selph,
counsels for
the Pan American
here.
Mr. Bixby requested that the bill
granting the franchise, already fil-
ed in the legislature, be passed as
soon as possible.
The Hongkong-
Manila airline, he stated, is
trainis to then operatil of the
The groundwork on the propos-
el airline, Mr. Bixby announced,
have already been completed and
two airplanes, especially built for
the trans oceanic hop, have been
ordered.
These special planes are
capable of doing
150
miles per
hour and will carry from 10 to 16
passengers each. When the line is
in operation, weekly round trips to
Hongkong will be conducted. The
Manila-Hongkong line will connect
with other air routes the company
is maintaining at present in China.
Senator Quirino,
in reply, said
that no assurance could be given
that the franchise bill would be
pushed through.. He explained
that according to a suggestion of
the Governor General, the legisla-
ture is studying a plan to transfer
to the department of public works
and communication's
the supervi-
sion and control
as well as the
right to grant certificates to aerial
lines•
Due to this impending change of
policy, he said, the granting of the
franchise
may be delayed
for a
while.
At
present, according to
law, no aerial line can operate in
the Philippines without the permis
sion
of
the
legislature made
through a franchise bill.
Mr. Quirino, however, promised
to consider the request carefully,
and said that as soon as the mat-
ter of transfering
the
power to
grant franchises is decided, quick
action
would taken on the Pan
American franchise.
Rates for the passengers,
mail
and light valuable cargo to be car-
ried by the sea planes of the Pan-
American Airways in the proposed
airline between Hongkong and Ma-
nila are being studied now.
Mr. Bixby indicated that most
likely the Pan-American will adopt
the schedule fixed during the in-
ternational convention in Europe
of air companies all over the world.
He will confer with Director Ruiz
of posts to get data on the amount
of mail and the probable share of
the sea planes of this volume of
mail.
The planes will also carry
such light merchandise as jewelry.
films, medical supplies, etc.
Negotiations for acquiring a cer-
tain space
in San Diego island,
Lingayen, to be used as a refuel-
ling base will be conducted during
Mr. Bixby's stay here. He will also
confer with Captain Maughan of
the aeronautics division on steps
along lines of establishing bases
and radio stations.

properties.sfomuseum:description: Clipping with headline “Bixby, Quirino Discuss Plan / Airways Franchise May Suffer Delay Due To Change Of Aerial Policy”; undated, with “Sept. 25, 1933” hand written at top; includes note in Mr. Bixby’s handwriting “Hardly any of the above is true and I never saw the reporter.”
properties.wof:name: clipping: Harold M. Bixby
